p: The major cell receptors for epidemic human coronaviruses are for SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) and for MERS, dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) (Table 1). For continuously circulating human species, HCoV-NL63 uses the ACE2 receptor, and neutralizing antibodies to HCoV-NL63 have been found in virtually all adults (Hofmann et al. 2005). Furthermore, HCoV-NL63 and SARS-CoV recognize the same motifs in ACE2 with their receptor binding domains (Perlman and Masters 2020). While sharing a common receptor, characteristics of viralâ€“host cell interactions vary between species: SARS-CoV binds and downregulates ACE2 with greater efficiency than HCoV-NL63, and SARS-CoV-2 demonstrates even greater binding efficiency for ACE2 than SARS-CoV (Hofmann et al. 2005; Glowacka et al. 2010; Wang et al. 2020). HCoV-229E uses aminopeptidase N (APN, also known as CD13) as its major receptor, and binding motifs for HCoVs OC43 and HKU1 are N-acetyl-9- O-acetylneuraminic acids (9- O-acetylsialic acids) (Hulswit et al. 2019; Perlman and Masters 2020).
